content.raw:
I think I've fixed this test in f7fe3a9.

`Node::ProcessPublishers()` is using an iterator to loop through all the publishers for calling `SendMessage()`. The loop was protected with `Node::publisherDeleteMutex` but not with `Node::publisherMutex`. If other thread adds a new publisher to `this->publishers` (for example executing `Node::Advertise()`) can cause a new internal allocation in the std::vector `Node::publishers` and invalidate the iterator in the `for` loop.
content.html:
I think I've fixed this test in f7fe3a9.

Node::ProcessPublishers() is using an iterator to loop through all the publishers for calling SendMessage(). The loop was protected with Node::publisherDeleteMutex but not with Node::publisherMutex. If other thread adds a new publisher to this->publishers (for example executing Node::Advertise()) can cause a new internal allocation in the std::vector Node::publishers and invalidate the iterator in the for loop.

content.raw: Something to note, just as we won't be supporting gazebo5 on precise due to an old default gcc, we will also have problems with Mac OSX 10.8 since it uses libstdc++ by default, while c++11 requires libc++. We should support OSX 10.9+ for gazebo5.
content.html: Something to note, just as we won't be supporting gazebo5 on precise due to an old default gcc, we will also have problems with Mac OSX 10.8 since it uses libstdc++ by default, while c++11 requires libc++. We should support OSX 10.9+ for gazebo5.

content.raw: We are adjusting the standard library (libc++ here) considering the compiler instead of the platform. I would try to use libstdc++ in Linux even when compiling with Clang. It is fine to use libc++ in Mac.
content.html: We are adjusting the standard library (libc++ here) considering the compiler instead of the platform. I would try to use libstdc++ in Linux even when compiling with Clang. It is fine to use libc++ in Mac.

content.raw:
Ummm it was not a matter of compiler vs platform in the conditionals. Let's say:

 * When I'm using GCC (no matter the plaform, are many) I want libstdc++
 * When I'm using Clang on Linux, I want libstdc++
 * When I'm using Clang on Mac (and probably Windows), I want libc++

So let's back to our conditionals using compilers but consider the case of Clang in Linux.
Thanks.
content.html:
Ummm it was not a matter of compiler vs platform in the conditionals. Let's say:

  • When I'm using GCC (no matter the plaform, are many) I want libstdc++
  • When I'm using Clang on Linux, I want libstdc++
  • When I'm using Clang on Mac (and probably Windows), I want libc++

So let's back to our conditionals using compilers but consider the case of Clang in Linux. Thanks.

content.html: Right. We just need to decide how to proceed: if hack something evil sed command for a massive replacement or progressively changing code with small pull requests.

content.raw: The API between the boost and std smart pointers is pretty much the same. We could try to replace them in a different pull request.
content.html: The API between the boost and std smart pointers is pretty much the same. We could try to replace them in a different pull request.

content.raw: Yes, this could happen in another pull request. I'm just not sure how it will fit with feature freeze. @nkoenig
content.html: Yes, this could happen in another pull request. I'm just not sure how it will fit with feature freeze. @nkoenig

content.html: In any case we can live with boost pointers for a while.

content.raw:
We are not in a hurry, and that big change (in terms of code being modified) fits much better in a new development cycle.

My vote: wait for gazebo6.
content.html:
We are not in a hurry, and that big change (in terms of code being modified) fits much better in a new development cycle.

content.raw: Sounds good
content.html: Sounds good

content.raw:
We could replace all boost::shared_ptr by std::shared_ptr and that could work, yes.

But, in that case we will be probably ignoring the concept of ownership, present in std::unique_ptr and std::shared_ptr. I can bet 5 eurocents that we have a good bunch of boost::shared_ptr that could be converted into unique_ptr.
content.html:
We could replace all boost::shared_ptr by std::shared_ptr and that could work, yes.

But, in that case we will be probably ignoring the concept of ownership, present in std::unique_ptr and std::shared_ptr. I can bet 5 eurocents that we have a good bunch of boost::shared_ptr that could be converted into unique_ptr.

content.raw: Agreed but that's a different topic and that's why boost has the `scoped_ptr`.
content.html: Agreed but that's a different topic and that's why boost has the scoped_ptr.

#!/osrf/gazebo/src/e27165f534c7b667789930047f24b5a9aa9d296b/tools/cppcheck_rules/issue_581.rule?at=default
